En la sociedad victoriana, era común que las parejas se comprometieran antes de casarse, y esta costumbre reflejaba la moralidad y las expectativas sociales de la época. Sin embargo, en la actualidad, las cosas han cambiado y la promesa de matrimonio ha perdido gran parte de su significado legal y social. Aunque la promesa puede ser un paso importante en la relación, no implica automáticamente un compromiso legal. En muchos casos, las parejas prefieren esperar hasta el matrimonio para formalizar su relación.

I fancy that the true explanation is this: It often happens that the real tragedies of life occur in such an inartistic manner that they hurt us by their crude violence, their absolute incoherence, their absurd want of meaning, their entire lack of style. They affect us just as vulgarity affects us. They give us an impression of sheer brute force, and we revolt against that. Sometimes, however, a tragedy that possesses artistic elements of beauty crosses our lives. If these elements of beauty are real, the whole thing simply appeals to our sense of dramatic effect. en_second_half: and the mere wonder of the spectacle enthralls us. In the present case, what is it that has really happened? Some one has killed herself for love of you. I wish that I had ever had such an experience. It would have made me in love with love for the rest of my life. The people who have adored me—there have not been very many, but there have been some—have always insisted on living on, long after I had ceased to care for them, or they to care for me. They have become stout and tedious, and when I meet them, they go in at once for reminiscences. That awful memory of woman! What a fearful thing it is! The relentless pursuit of beauty and pleasure had become a prison, one he could not escape. The mirror that had once reflected the face of a young and handsome man now held the visage of a man ravaged by time and sin. Each day, he found himself drawn deeper into a cycle of self-destruction, his actions driven by a desire to avoid the inevitable. Yet, in his darkest moments, he found himself questioning the very nature of his existence. Was he truly free, or was he bound by the very passions that had once set him apart? The answer, he realized, was not in the pursuit of pleasure, but in the acceptance of his own humanity. As the night wore on, Dorian Gray found himself standing before the mirror, not as a man of sin, but as a man of reflection. The future, he knew, was uncertain, but the past was a lesson he would never forget. The wild desire to live, though still present, was now tempered by a newfound understanding of the fleeting nature of life. In the end, it was not the passions that defined him, but the choices he made in the face of them. And as the dawn broke, Dorian Gray stepped into a new day, ready to face the challenges that lay ahead, with a heart both broken and whole.
